discussion.content:
It is C.
https://www.claudiokuenzler.com/blog/882/cannot-start-aws-ec2-instance-ensure-enabled-ena

Selected Answer: C
C: ENA is a network interface for Amazon EC2 instances. ENA provides superior performance characteristics relative to the currently available network interfaces, including higher IOPS, lower latency, and higher bandwidth. x2gd.16xlarge instances require ENA support. If ENA drivers are not installed before changing the instance type to an instance type that requires ENA support, the instance check will fail.
C is correct

Selected Answer: C
Option C is correct.

The cause of the problem is that the operations engineer did not install Elastic Network Adapter (ENA) drivers before changing the instance type. The r4.16xlarge instance type uses the Intel 82599 network interface card (NIC), while the x2gd.16xlarge instance type uses the Elastic Network Adapter (ENA) NIC. The ENA driver is required for the new instance type to work properly

Option D is incorrect because creating a new AMI from the original instance and launching a new instance with dedicated tenancy from the AMI is not required for this migration.

https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/TroubleshootingInstances.html

Selected Answer: C
Graviton2 needs ENA.

C.

The most likely cause of the failed instance status check is that the operations engineer did not install Elastic Network Adapter (ENA) drivers before changing the instance type. The r4.16xlarge instance type is based on an older generation of AWS instance types that do not require ENA drivers. However, the x2gd.16xlarge instance type is based on a newer generation that requires ENA drivers to be installed before changing the instance type. Without the ENA drivers, the network interface of the instance will fail to start, causing the instance status check to fail. To resolve the problem, the operations engineer should install the ENA drivers on the instance before changing the instance type.

Selected Answer: D
D: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/launching-instance.html

questions.question_text:
A company runs its SAP ERP 6.0 EHP 8 system on SAP HANA on AWS. The system is deployed on an r4.16xlarge Amazon EC2 instance with default tenancy. The company needs to migrate the SAP HANA database to an x2gd.16xlarge High Memory instance. After an operations engineer changes the instance type and starts the instance, the AWS Management Console shows a failed instance status check.
What is the cause of this problem?

choices.A: The operations engineer missed the network configuration step during the post-migration activities.
choices.B: The operations engineer missed the Amazon CloudWatch configuration step during the post-migration activities.
choices.C: The operations engineer did not install Elastic Network Adapter (ENA) drivers before changing the instance type.
choices.D: The operations engineer did not create a new AMI from the original instance and did not launch a new instance with dedicated tenancy from the AMI.

choices.B: Migrate by using SAP Software Update Manager (SUM) Database Migration Option (DMO) with System Move. Use an AWS Snowball Edge Storage Optimized device to transfer the SAP export files to AWS.
choices.A: Migrate by using SAP HANA system replication over the internet connection. Specify a public IP address on the target system.
choices.C: Migrate by using SAP HANA system replication with initialization through backup and restore. Use an AWS Snowball Edge Storage Optimized device to transfer the SAP export files to AWS.
choices.D: Migrate by using SAP Software Update Manager (SUM) Database Migration Option (DMO) with System Move. Use Amazon Elastic File System (Amazon EFS) to transfer the SAP export files to AWS.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B. Migrate by using SAP Software Update Manager (SUM) Database Migration Option (DMO) with System Move. Use an AWS Snowball Edge Storage Optimized device to transfer the SAP export files to AWS.
I think B - https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sap/latest/sap-hana/migrating-hana-tools.html#migrating-hana-snowball

Selected Answer: B
B: Given the unreliable internet connection, using the AWS Snowball Edge device to physically transfer data is a good option. The SUM DMO with System Move option allows migration and conversion of the database to SAP HANA in one step, which reduces downtime.

questions.question_text:
A company is running SAP on anyDB at a remote location that has slow and inconsistent internet connectivity. The company wants to migrate its system to AWS and wants to convert its database to SAP HANA during this process. Because of the inconsistent internet connection, the company has not established connectivity between the remote location and the companyâ€™s VPC in the AWS Cloud.
How should the company perform this migration?

choices.A: Set up SAP Solution Manager to call Amazon CloudWatch and Amazon EC2 endpoints with REST-based calls to populate SAPOSCOL details. Use SAP transaction ST06N to monitor CPU and memory utilization on each EC2 instance.
choices.C: Install the AWS Data Provider for SAP on the Amazon EC2 instances that host SAP. Create VPC endpoints for Amazon CloudWatch and Amazon EC2. Allow access through these endpoints. Create an IAM policy that allows the ec2:DescribeInstances action, the cloudwatch:GetMetricStatistics action, and the ec2:DescribeVolumes action for all EC2 resources.
choices.B: Install the AWS Data Provider for SAP on the Amazon EC2 instances that host SAP. Allow access to the Amazon CloudWatch and EC2 endpoints through a NAT gateway. Create an IAM policy that allows the ec2:DescribeInstances action, the cloudwatch:GetMetricStatistics action, and the ec2:DescribeVolumes action for all EC2 resources.
choices.D: Install the AWS Data Provider for SAP on the Amazon EC2 instances that host SAP. Create VPC endpoints for Amazon CloudWatch and Amazon EC2. Allow access through these endpoints. Create an IAM policy that allows all actions for all EC2 resources.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C: The AWS Data Provider for SAP collects OS and Amazon CloudWatch metrics and makes them available to SAP applications. By creating VPC endpoints for Amazon CloudWatch and Amazon EC2, the company ensures that no traffic traverses the public internet. The IAM policy is needed to allow the AWS Data Provider for SAP to call these services.

Selected Answer: C
Voting C

Selected Answer: C
Its C and not D because principle of least privilege

Selected Answer: C
C is the right choice

Selected Answer: C
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sap/latest/general/data-provider-req.html#vpc-endpoints
I think C

Selected Answer: C
has to be C

questions.question_text:
A financial services company is implementing SAP core banking on AWS. The company must not allow any system information to traverse the public internet. The company needs to implement secure monitoring of its SAP ERP Central Component (SAP ECC) system to check for performance issues and faults in its application. The solution must maximize security and must be supported by SAP and AWS.
How should the company integrate AWS metrics with its SAP system to meet these requirements?

choices.B: Use the AWS CLI to stop the current instance. Change the instance type to u-18tb1.metal. Start the instance.
choices.D: Use the AWS Management Console to stop the current instance. Create an AMI from the current instance. Use the new AMI to launch a new u-18tb1.metal instance with dedicated tenancy.
choices.C: Use the AWS CLI to stop the current instance. Create an AMI from the current instance. Use the new AMI to launch a new u-18tb1.metal instance with host tenancy.
choices.A: Use the AWS Management Console to stop the current instance. Change the instance type to u-18tb1.metal. Start the instance.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
As mentioned by the others here, the instance needs host tenancy. So C

Voting C

C, since u-*tb1.metal instances can be launched only with host tenancy..

comments.content: Not D, its C: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/autoscaling/ec2/userguide/auto-scaling-dedicated-instances.html - metal MUST be host tenancy, so Option 2(b) Step 6: "Launch a new EC2 High Memory instance with host tenancy for u-*tb1.metal instances"

Option 2: Migrating from an Existing EC2 Instance with Default Tenancy

questions.question_text:
A company is running SAP S/4HANA on AWS. The company has deployed its current database infrastructure on a u-12tb1.112xlarge Amazon EC2 instance that uses default tenancy and SUSE Linux Enterprise Server for SAP 15 SP1. The company must scale its SAP HANA database to an instance with more RAM. An SAP solutions architect needs to migrate the database to a u-18tb1.metal High Memory instance.

How can the SAP solutions architect meet this requirement?

A company has a 48 TB SAP application that runs on premises and uses an IBM Db2 database. The company needs to migrate the application to AWS. The company has strict uptime requirements for the application with maximum downtime of 24 hours each weekend. The company has established a 1 Gbps AWS Direct Connect connection but can spare bandwidth for migration only during non-business hours or weekends.

How can the company meet these requirements to migrate the application to AWS?

choices.C: Use an AWS Snowball Edge Storage Optimized device to send an initial backup to AWS. Capture incremental backups daily. When the initial backup is on AWS, perform database restore from the initial backup and keep applying incremental backups. On the day of cutover, perform the final incremental backup. Perform cutover to AWS.
choices.B: Set up database replication from on premises to AWS. On the day of downtime, ensure that the replication finishes. Perform cutover to AWS.
choices.A: Use SAP Software Provisioning Manager to create an export of the data. Move this export to AWS during a weekend by using the Direct Connect connection. On AWS. import the data into the target SAP application. Perform the cutover.
choices.D: Use AWS Application Migration Service (CloudEndure Migration) to migrate the database to AWS. On the day of cutover, switch the application to run on AWS servers.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C: This solution allows the company to migrate the large database within the required timeframe. AWS Snowball Edge provides a fast, secure, and offline way to transfer large amounts of data into and out of the AWS Cloud. After the initial backup is transferred, the company can use the AWS Direct Connect connection to transfer incremental backups during non-business hours or weekends, minimizing disruption to business operations.

Selected Answer: C
Option C. use an AWS Snowball Edge Storage Optimized device to send an initial backup to AWS. Capture incremental backups daily. When the initial backup is on AWS, perform database restore from the initial backup and keep applying incremental backups. On the day of cutover, perform the final incremental backup. Perform cutover to AWS.

Option A is incorrect because it requires downtime for the application during the export and import process.

Option B is incorrect because it requires downtime for the application during the replication process.

Option D is incorrect because it does not meet the bandwidth requirement of 1 Gbps during non-business hours or weekends.
I think is D

exam.name: AWS Certified SAP on AWS - Specialty PAS-C01
